problems.prompt: The point of view from which the passage is told is best described as that of:

options.A: a young adult riding a train through the small towns of the Upper Midwest.
options.B: a young adult preparing to move away from her hometown.
options.C: an adult missing the new home she has established.
options.D: an adult reflecting on the past and pondering the present.

problems.prompt: The passage contains recurring references to all of the following EXCEPT:

options.J: train trips.

problems.prompt: The first three paragraphs (lines 1–21) establish all of the following about the narrator EXCEPT that she is:

options.A: passing through a number of towns.
options.B: originally from Chicago.
options.C: traveling by train.
options.D: observant of the landscape.

problems.prompt: It can reasonably be inferred from the passage that the narrator thinks her hometown has:

options.H: remained about the same as it was years ago
options.J: a chance of being rebuilt as it used to be.

problems.prompt: Based on the narrator’s account, all of the following were part of the past, rather than the present, in her hometown EXCEPT:

options.A: four-digit phone numbers.
options.B: the fenced-in football field.
options.C: free ice cream during dairy month.
options.D: the depot.

problems.prompt: According to the narrator, which of the following businesses is relatively new to her hometown?

options.J: The used-car lot

problems.prompt: When the narrator refers to the cosmonaut as “a man without a country” (lines 83–84), she is most likely directly referring to the:

options.A: cosmonaut’s feeling that he is now a citizen of space, not the former Soviet Union.
options.B: cosmonaut’s unrealized expectation that he will be treated like a hero.
options.C: political transformation that occurred while the cosmonaut was in space.
options.D: sixteen months that the cosmonaut spent in orbit around Earth.

problems.prompt: Details in the passage most strongly suggest that the people meeting the narrator at the train station include:

options.J: a journalist.

problems.prompt: The narrator indicates that the most significant change to her hometown has been the addition of:

options.A: square dancing.
options.B: vinyl storefronts.
options.C: benches on Main Street.
options.D: Las Vegas–style gambling.

problems.prompt: According to the passage, news reports attributed the cosmonaut’s knees buckling to:

options.F: his gratitude at being back on Earth.
options.J: his dismay at what he had seen from the space station.

problems.prompt: Which of the following assumptions would be most critical for a reader to accept in order to agree fully with the author’s claims in the passage?

options.A: Shantytowns in the Amazon need to be relocated if the forest is to be saved.
options.B: Learning to make consistently good guitars requires access to the best materials available.
options.C: Small-scale rural producers in the Amazon can help preserve the forest by being innovative.
options.D: Consumers outside of the Amazon can do little to help prevent deforestation.

problems.prompt: In the context of the passage, the statement “All the guitars are made from certified wood” (lines 34–35) most nearly suggests that Gomes’s workshop:

options.F: uses environmentally sustainable woods in its guitars.
options.G: isn’t doing enough to stop unnecessary deforestation in the Amazon.
options.H: has little chance of pleasing both musicians and environmentalists.
options.J: uses only traditional woods in making its guitars.

problems.prompt: It can most reasonably be inferred from the passage that regarding OELA, the author feels:

options.A: skeptical of the workshop’s aims.
options.B: dismayed by the workshop’s low productivity.
options.C: supportive of the workshop’s goals.
options.D: confident that the workshop could be duplicated in other places.

problems.prompt: The main purpose of the second paragraph (lines 6–18) is to:

options.F: draw attention to the Amazon’s tremendous population growth.
options.G: explain the necessity for ventures such as Gomes’s.
options.H: explain the presence of the Ford Foundation in the Amazon.
options.J: justify raising taxes to increase social services in the Amazon.

problems.prompt: The main function of the fifth paragraph (lines 33–53) is to:

options.A: demonstrate the woodworking skills required to be a master luthier.
options.B: explore the limitations of science as compared to intuition.
options.C: outline the scientific reasons why one type of wood cannot be replaced by another.
options.D: show that experiments led to the discovery of good substitutes for rare woods.

problems.prompt: The passage notes all of the following as problems that the fledgling Amazon guitar industry has experienced EXCEPT that:

options.F: glue on the guitars sometimes doesn’t hold.
options.G: the wood used may crack in drier climates.
options.H: woods usable for guitars have become extinct.
options.J: buyers resist guitars made with nontraditional woods.

problems.prompt: The passage indicates that, as a group, the OELA students may impact the survival of the rain forests because most of them:

options.A: care deeply enough about music to spend their lives making musical instruments.
options.B: will return to their homes and spread their environmental knowledge.
options.C: are willing to endure personal hardships in order to use their new skills.
options.D: will have political careers after they return home.

problems.prompt: In the passage, Gomes indicates that of the wood cut in the Amazon rain forest each year, approximately how much wood is wasted?

options.J: Two-thirds

problems.prompt: The passage states that all of the following are woods traditionally used for making stringed instruments EXCEPT:

options.A: Aniba canellila.
options.B: rosewood.
options.C: Brazilian mahogany
options.D: ebony.

problems.prompt: According to the passage, when an OELA student is “adopted,” he or she receives:

options.J: a musical instrument.

problems.prompt: The passage is best described as being told from the point of view of a philosopher who is:

options.A: discussing metaphysical questions that have troubled philosophers since the time of Descartes.
options.B: presenting in chronological order the key events in his thirty-year professional career
options.C: reflecting on his own early, developing interest in philosophy and in scholarship generally.
options.D: advising professional educators on how to get more students to study philosophy.

problems.prompt: Based on the passage, which of the following was most likely the first to engage the author’s passionate interest?

options.J: Butterflies

problems.prompt: The main purpose of the last paragraph is to:

options.A: reveal the enduring impact of Mr. Marsh’s lessons on the author.
options.B: acknowledge that the author came to doubt some of Mr. Marsh’s teachings.
options.C: describe a typical class as taught by Mr. Marsh.
options.D: present a biographical sketch of Mr. Marsh.

problems.prompt: The passage indicates that the man in the book-cover photograph represents:

options.F: Descartes, wondering what could be known.
options.G: Mr. Marsh, deep in scholarly thought.
options.H: the author at age seventeen, thinking about enrolling in college.
options.J: the author at age eighteen, contemplating a philosophical issue.

problems.prompt: The author mentions Melody Maker, the top 20, and articles about musicians primarily to suggest that his:

options.A: early interest in music has remained with him to the present.
options.B: time spent playing music should instead have been spent reading.
options.C: fascination with pop music and musicians gave focus to his life for a time.
options.D: commitment to study enabled him to perfect his drumming technique.

problems.prompt: In the third paragraph (lines 36–56), the author most nearly characterizes the energy he refers to as:

options.F: potent yet difficult to channel in a constructive way
options.G: powerful and typically leading to destructive results.
options.H: delicate and inevitably wasted in trivial undertakings.
options.J: gentle yet capable of uniting people who have different interests.

problems.prompt: Viewed in the context of the passage, the statement in lines 55–56 is most likely intended to suggest that:

options.A: schools should require students to take philosophy courses.
options.B: students can become passionate when learning about science in school.
options.C: schools need to keep searching for ways to tap into students’ deeply held interests.
options.D: students should resolve to take school courses that interest them.

problems.prompt: The author calls pen and paper “rudimentary tools” (line 80) as part of his argument that:

options.F: the use of computers has made the use of pen and paper obsolete.
options.G: students should become skilled with pen and paper before moving on to better tools.
options.H: while writing with pen and paper can be pleasant, it can also be physically painful.
options.J: although seemingly simple, pen and paper allow people to perform great feats.

problems.prompt: In the context of the passage, lines 17–23 are best described as presenting images of:

options.A: gloom, tension, and fascination.
options.B: anger, bitterness, and betrayal.
options.C: stillness, peacefulness, and relaxation.
options.D: frustration, surprise, and satisfaction.

problems.prompt: Which of the following does NOT reasonably describe the transition the author presents in lines 80–84?

options.J: Private to public

problems.prompt: One of the main ideas established by the passage is that:

options.A: researchers have nearly exhausted their resources after spending decades investigating the Sargasso Sea.
options.B: significant gaps still remain in researchers’ understanding of the life cycle of eels.
options.C: eels live their entire lives in the Sargasso Sea, but no one has ever seen them there.
options.D: female eels turn into silver eels toward the end of their lives.

problems.prompt: Learning about which of the following had the largest impact on scientists’ current understanding of where eels breed?

options.F: The direction in which ocean currents carry eel larvae
options.G: The relationship of the yellow eel stage to the silver eel stage
options.H: Schmidt’s discovery of eel larvae in the Sargasso Sea
options.J: The adult eels found in the stomachs of other fish

problems.prompt: The main purpose of the fourth paragraph (lines 34–47) is to describe the:

options.A: eels’ transition from freshwater to the ocean.
options.B: method of determining the age of eels.
options.C: complexity of the Mississippi River system
options.D: river stage of the eel life cycle.

problems.prompt: The passage states that the Sargasso Sea is set off from the rest of the Atlantic Ocean by:

options.J: strong currents.

problems.prompt: The passage notes that the Sargasso Sea includes:

options.A: the eastern North American shore.
options.B: the Bermuda Triangle.
options.C: certain coastal estuaries.
options.D: the mouth of the Mississippi River

problems.prompt: As it is used in line 13, the word popular most nearly means:

options.J: most admired.

problems.prompt: As it is used in line 45, the word read most nearly means to:

options.A: learn from print.
options.B: observe.
options.C: think about.
options.D: predict.

problems.prompt: The passage indicates that female eels’ pupils expand and turn blue because the eels:

options.F: must adapt to see in an environment with much less light than they are used to.
options.G: are about to undergo a change in their blood chemistry.
options.H: no longer need to be able to recognize food sources since they have stopped eating.
options.J: need to be able to recognize the male eels that will fertilize their eggs.

problems.prompt: The passage most strongly emphasizes that the process of osmosis is necessary for the eels’ transition from:

options.A: shallower to deeper water.
options.B: feeding to nonfeeding.
options.C: immature to mature form.
options.D: elver to yellow eel.

problems.prompt: According to the passage, which of the following characteristics of the eel larvae found by Schmidt provided the best evidence that the larvae were hatched in the Sargasso Sea?

options.J: Species
